title:
Office of eLearning
Isidore Training Modules
description: Below are training modules and lessons developed by the Office of eLearning to help folks use Isidore, UD's learning management system.

badges.title: Participation Trophy
badges.description: Do you earn this badge for doing anything impressive? Nope. All you do is log into the system, and poof! You get the badge. You participated. Take your trophy. You are now prepared for your first steps in the Office of E-Learning's online training. DISCLAIMER: Always consult your physician before beginning any online training program. This is not intended to diagnose any medical condition or to replace your health care professional. If you experience any pain or shortness of breath with these online modules, stop and consult your physician.

badges.title: Is-A-Door
badges.description: Isidore. If you know what it is and you know what it does, it will open all kinds of doors for your teaching career here at UD. The name of the badge will also serve as a reminder of the proper pronunciation. eLearning hears a lot of eyes-a-dore and Isadora type stuff. No good! You wouldn't want to bring dishonor on Saint Isidore of Seville, the patron saint of students and the Internet, would you? This badge is awarded for completing the What Is Isidore? lesson.

badges.title: Onboarded
badges.description: Earning this badge proves that you are on-board. You're not the captain of the ship. Heck. You're not even a crew member. But you're on the boat, and you earned your spot by completing the I'm Brand New module.

badges.title: Site Sighted
badges.description: Creating a site in Isidore is the most important thing you will ever do. At any point of your life. No matter what. It may even save your life. This badge is awarded following a validation (or observational sighting) of an Isidore site you created as part of the Course Site Creation lesson.

badges.title: Gen Ed
badges.description: Like the general ed courses for undergrads, this badge is awarded for those that have completed the Isidore 101 modules, which teaches on the fundamental tools of Isidore. And just like those general ed, Isidore 101 prepares you for your next steps in learning Isidore, your next steps in teaching, and your next steps in becoming the best instructor this institution has ever seen!

badges.title: Feelin' Dangerous
badges.description: Have you ever heard the expression, You know enough to be dangerous? Well, that's you right now. This badge is earned following the completion of both the I'm Brand New and Isidore 101 modules. At this point you're ready to start doing some great things with Isidore. But we need to be clear that the dangerous thing is just an expression. We don't suggest you ever put yourself in a position where you feel or create true danger. Just be cool, ok?

badges.title: Header
badges.description: Headers are important in soccer but this badge is awarded to those that know that headers are important in online content as well. Alt text and closed captions are important as well, but they are not used quite as often in soccer. Well, you could probably find some closed captions on a televised soccer match.

badges.title: Creative Caring
badges.description: The CC symbol stands for Closed Captions, but those that earn this badge understand that accessibility is also about Creative Caring. Instructors do not need to suppress their creativity to keep their content accessible. In fact, universal design tends to be best for everyone.

modules.title: Preparing Your Isidore Course Site for the Fall 2020 Semester
modules.description:
In effort to support faculty, the Office of eLearning has created all fall 2020 Isidore sites from a standard template with a set of standard tools and organization guided by best practices and student needs. With everyone learning how to use the same tools in Isidore, we can provide more effective training that will help guide you step-by-step through creating polished Isidore sites that are easy and consistent for students to navigate.

Completing this training package should take no longer than an hour and a half. We recommend starting with the very first lesson, but you can also jump to the lessons you need by exploring the outline within this training package.

lessons.title: Getting Started With Your Site
lessons.description: Start with the basics.
lessons.overviewcontent: Let’s start with the basics. What would your students see in the template site? What tools are in the template site? We’ll cover these questions in the videos for this lesson.

lessons.title: The Big Picture
lessons.description: Learn about the importance of creating a consistent learning experience for students.
lessons.overviewcontent: The ultimate goal of the template site is to create a consistent learning experience for students. So, let’s start with what the students will actually see. In this video, you’ll see how streamlined and easy it is for the student to know exactly where to go for your course communications, your content, their due dates, and their grades and feedback.

lessons.title: Understanding the Template
lessons.description: A quick walkthrough of each tool in the template site.
lessons.overviewcontent: Before diving into the details of every tool, this video is just a quick walkthrough of the basic purpose of each tool that is in the template site.

lessons.title: Structuring Your Course Content
lessons.description: Designing your course.
lessons.overviewcontent: The importance of planning out your course and providing a solid structure your course content can not be overstated. These are essential first steps in constructing and delivering a quality course. There are many key decisions that must be made up front that inform how a course will ultimately be constructed.

lessons.title: Planning Your Course
lessons.description: A look at backwards design, scheduling, assessment and course content.
lessons.overviewcontent: Before adding any content to Isidore, we suggest taking some time to think through your entire course on paper. What are the goals for the course? Do your assessments appropriately measure those goals? How will you split out all the content for your course?

lessons.title: Creating a Course Plan
lessons.description: Learn how to use the Course Planner tool to easily lay out the key elements of your course.
lessons.overviewcontent: The Isidore Course Planner tool is a simple utility designed to help faculty start laying out the key elements of a course. It also provides a great way to visualize how all of the elements will fit together. Faculty can create as many individual course plans as they want and each course plan can be shared with colleagues for easy collaboration. This tool does not connect to a specific Isidore site and is not designed to be shared with students. It's a place to get started as you think through any course.

lessons.title: Taking the First Steps
lessons.description: Beginning to add content to Isidore.
lessons.overviewcontent: Now that you’ve thought through how you want to design your course, it’s time to start taking those first steps of adding content to Isidore. In this Lesson, we’ll cover creating a useful and attractive course homepage, updating your syllabus, and adding your topics and dates to a templated schedule.

lessons.title: Creating Your Homepage
lessons.description: Providing students with a central place for important information.
lessons.overviewcontent: Your course homepage should provide students with the most important information they need to get started with your class. This video will show you how to add your course details to the Homepage Builder tool to give them a personalized welcome.

lessons.title: Updating Your Syllabus
lessons.description: Getting started with the syllabus template.
lessons.overviewcontent: It can be challenging to develop your syllabus without knowing exactly what your course will look like. We have created a syllabus template that adheres to the best practices of Flexible Teaching. In this video, we’ll review the most important parts of the syllabus and how to update it yourself. We’ll also show you how to save it as a PDF so it can be accessed easily by all students.

references.title: Flexible Teaching Guide: How to Create a Strong Syllabus

lessons.title: Planning Your Schedule
lessons.description: Creating an easy-to-update course schedule.
lessons.overviewcontent: Similar to the syllabus, it can be tricky to plan out the schedule for the entire semester. We’ve created an easy-to-update schedule that we recommend you complete to the best of your ability before the semester begins. If it needs to change throughout the semester, you can quickly update and re-upload to your Homepage in Isidore.

lessons.title: Creating & Adding Your Course Content
lessons.description: Building your course's content in Isidore.
lessons.overviewcontent: It’s time to start adding content to the Lessons tool in the template. We’ll walk you through the whole process, step-by-step. We’ll also cover in this lesson the best ways to record and share video lectures.

lessons.title: Introduction Module
lessons.description: Adding content to your introduction module in the Lessons tool.
lessons.overviewcontent: Rather than spending a class session talking through the syllabus and course procedures, ask students to look through this material in your Introduction module.

references.title: The Chronicle: The Absolute Worst Way to Start a Semester

lessons.title: Building Your Weekly Modules
lessons.description: Adding content to the weekly modules in the Lessons tool.
lessons.overviewcontent: The course template contains weekly modules. Each module should contain all the information a student needs to complete course activities for that week. Let’s walk through how you can set these up.

lessons.title: Importing Content from Previous Isidore Sites
lessons.description: Learn how to re-use your content in your new site.
lessons.overviewcontent: We know you’ve spent many years building out assignments, tests, forums, and more. You can easily still use this material. In this video, you’ll learn how to import content from your previous Isidore sites.

videos.title: Lesson 4: Importing Content from Previous Isidore Sites

lessons.title: Adding More Tools
lessons.description: Add missing tools to your new course site.
lessons.overviewcontent: If there are still tools missing from your course site, not to worry. It only takes 4 clicks to add back a tool.

lessons.title: Creating and Sharing Videos with Snagit and Warpwire
lessons.description: Learn the easiest approach to recording and sharing videos.
lessons.overviewcontent: Video is a powerful way to teach content to your students. Let’s take a look at the easiest approach to record and share your videos with students.

videos.title: Lesson 4: Creating and Sharing Videos with Snagit and Warpwire

references.title: Email elearning@udayton.edu for a Snagit license
How to Setup a DIY Teleprompter

lessons.title: Streamlining Communications
lessons.description: Learn how to keep your students on track throughout the semester by establishing a communication plan.
lessons.overviewcontent: Establishing a communication plan can help you and your students stay on track throughout the semester. The goal of a streamlined communication strategy is to engage with students frequently enough so that they can keep up with important course dates - but also to not overwhelm them with too many messages.

lessons.title: Communication Strategy
lessons.description: Establish expectations with your students.
lessons.overviewcontent: A key component of successful course communication is to establish expectations with your students. In this lesson, we’ll review expectations you can set in your Syllabus as well as different types of messages you might send throughout the semester.

references.title: 5 Low-Tech, Time-Saving Ways to Teach Online (#5 pertains to strategic communication)

lessons.title: Posting Announcements
lessons.description: Learn why the Announcements tool is the best way to send streamlined communications to your classes.
lessons.overviewcontent: The Announcements tool is the best way to send streamlined communications to your classes. We’ll explain why - and how to use it - in this video lesson.

references.title: When You Communicate with Students, Tone Matters

lessons.title: Fostering Community through Commons
lessons.description: Learn how to use the Commons tool available on your course homepage.
lessons.overviewcontent: The Commons tool is a social media style news feed that sits on your course site homepage. This tool gives your students a place to cultivate community by asking questions, sharing links and pictures, and commenting on each other’s posts.

references.title: 5 Ways to Connect with Online Students
Purposeful Interpersonal Interaction in Online Learning

lessons.title: Creating Groups for in-class Attendance
lessons.description: Learn one method for breaking your class into groups and telling students which days to attend class in-person.
lessons.overviewcontent:
Faculty will need to let students know what days they can attend if they're teaching a blended classes where all students can't be present in-person at the same.

Please see our 5 minute video demonstration below about how to create your groups and notify students. Feel free to use our email template to convey these groupings to your students (linked on this page).

videos.title: Lesson 5: Creating Groups for in-class Assignments

lessons.title: Assessing Your Students
lessons.description: Learn about techniques to assess your students' learning.
lessons.overviewcontent: Use Isidore to set up online activities to assess your students' learning. You may find that these techniques help you stay organized and save you time.

lessons.title: Collecting and Grading Assignments
lessons.description: Learn about assigning and grading homework, papers, and projects online.
lessons.overviewcontent: Assigning and grading homework, papers, and projects is one of the most foundational instructional practices. Learn the simplest way of accomplishing this online.

lessons.title: Delivering Quizzes and Exams
lessons.description: Learn about the Tests & Quizzes tool in Isidore.
lessons.overviewcontent: You can deliver online quizzes and exams through Isidore. See the student experience and learn how to use the most common question types.

references.title: Writing Good Multiple Choice Test Questions

lessons.title: Hosting & Evaluating Discussion Forums
lessons.description: Give your students a reprieve from "Zoom fatigue"
lessons.overviewcontent: Online discussion forums allow you to evaluate student participation and could give your students a reprieve from "Zoom fatigue".

references.title: 9 Student Engagement Strategies for Online Discussion Forums

lessons.title: Maintaining Your Gradebook
lessons.description: Learn about the most popular Isidore tool among students.
lessons.overviewcontent: The most popular of all Isidore tools among students, online gradebooks help students track their progress, while giving instructors the platform to publish grades and offer constructive feedback.

lessons.title: Creating Your Gradebook
lessons.description: Learn how to add gradebook items, enter grades and comments, and link items to other tools.
lessons.overviewcontent: Adding items, entering grades, leaving comments, and grading from other tools, such as Assignments and Tests & Quizzes. These are the fundamental functions of the Gradebook.

lessons.title: Configuring Your Gradebook
lessons.description: Learn how to configure your gradebook to your grading schema and specifications.
lessons.overviewcontent: Once you have established your online gradebook, you will want to configure it to your grading schema and specifications. In this video, you will learn how to reorder grade columns and create grading categories and weights, along with methods for including grades into the final course calculations or excluding them entirely.

lessons.title: Understanding the Calendar
lessons.description: Learn how you can create course calendar posts that help students stay on track.
lessons.overviewcontent: Students tell us that next to the gradebook the calendar tool is the most essential tool. Learn how you can create course calendar posts that help students stay on track.

lessons.title: Facilitating Zoom Sessions
lessons.description: A quick dive into the different ways to access Zoom and how to create and schedule meetings.
lessons.overviewcontent: Synchronous classes, one-on-one meetings, office hours, brainstorming, group work, presentations and more are essential parts to your course and your student’s growth in knowledge and skill. Zoom allows these to take place when distance is required. If you are just getting started or if you just need some additional information, this lesson will get you up and running in Zoom.

lessons.title: Accessing Zoom
lessons.description: Learn about the different ways to access Zoom.
lessons.overviewcontent: There are three ways you can access Zoom. In this video we will discuss what these three ways are, the differences between them, and how to know which is the best way to access and utilize Zoom for your particular purpose.

lessons.title: Adding Meetings
lessons.description: Learn how to create and schedule Zoom meetings.
lessons.overviewcontent: Meetings are where the magic happens. Here we discuss the difference between scheduled meetings and your personal meeting room. We will learn how to schedule class meetings as well as how to start spontaneous meetings.

references.title: Scheduling a Meeting in Google Calendar
How to Create Meetings with Unique Start Times

lessons.title: Starting and Managing Zoom Meetings
lessons.description: Learn how to start your scheduled meetings as the host.
lessons.overviewcontent: It’s class time and you need to get things rolling. In this video we discuss how to access your previously scheduled meetings and ensure that you start the meeting as The Host with the Most.

videos.title: Lesson 9: Starting and Managing Zoom Meetings

lessons.title: Managing Recordings
lessons.description: Learn how record and share recordings for your Zoom meetings.
lessons.overviewcontent: It is essential to record your synchronous sessions. This will provide a means for students who are unable to attend your live session to stay on top of their work. This session will show you where these recordings reside, how students access them, how to edit them, and how you can share in alternative ways if necessary.

lessons.title: Creating and Managing Breakout Rooms
lessons.description: Learn how to foster student engagement with Zoom breakout rooms.
lessons.overviewcontent: If group work and discussion are integral to your class then you will need to make friends with the breakout rooms in zoom! Breakout rooms are a great way to have your students collaborate on solving a problem, engage in active learning, make application of new knowledge, discuss a topic, and make connections. This video will show you have to facilitate breakouts. Check out our additional resources for more ideas on how to effectively use breakouts for student engagement.

videos.title: Lesson 9: Creating and Managing Zoom Breakout Rooms

lessons.title: Virtual Office Hours
lessons.description: Learn how to create office hours for multiple sections in Zoom or just one in Isidore.
lessons.overviewcontent: Having multiple points of contact helps to reassure students that you are available for them and invested in their success. Virtual office hours is a great way to meet with students who need some individual or small group feedback. Here, we will demonstrate how to set up recurring office hours for an individual course in Isidore or set up in general for multiple course rosters.

lessons.title: Leading a Class
lessons.description: Learn how to make your synchronous sessions engaging.
lessons.overviewcontent: Synchronous course sessions online should provide added value to your course. How do you motivate students to attend and be engaged with your live session? Here we will discuss practical uses of the Zoom features to help with engagement but more importantly valuable pedagogy for creating an engaging synchronous session.

references.title: Hosting an Engaging Zoom Session Recording
Managing the Tools of the Zoom Room

modules.title: I'm Brand New! What Do I Do?
modules.description: If you're brand new to Isidore, or just need a complete refresher, pop into any of the lessons below to learn the fundamentals. The topics covered include background information about Isidore, basic navigation and layout of the system, and the site creation process.

video.title: I'm Brand New! What Do I Do? Teaser

lessons.title: What Is Isidore?
lessons.description: And what does it do?

videos.title: What Is Isidore, And What Does It Do?

lessons.overviewcontent: Isidore is UD's open-source Learning Management System or LMS. Isidore is based on the Sakai LMS, but why did UD go this direction? Find out in this lesson.
lessons.section1content: Watch this 2-minute video for an introduction to Isidore.
lessons.section2content: Now it's time to prove you watched the video. Complete the Quick Quiz below and earn a badge.

lti.description: Take the three question quiz below to test your Isidore knowledge.
lti.title: What is Isidore? Quiz

references.title: Wiki Page for St. Isidore of Seville
Why Open Source? - Written by eLearning Staff

aside2questions.question: So Isidore is open-source. What features have you built or customized for UD?
aside2questions.answer: The Attendance tool, the Checklist feature in Lessons, various Learning Apps, and this very training platform! We share these features with the broader open-source community so they are used worldwide. If you want to see all of our work, check out our Isidore Releases page linked in 'Additional Articles' above.

aside2questions.question: I have a feature request! How do I let you know?
aside2questions.answer: Just call or email the Office of eLearning! We are available at (937) 229-5039 and elearning@udayton.edu. We'll make a ticket for you, and we'll be sure to let you know when the feature is added to Isidore.

aside2questions.question: How is 'Isidore' pronounced?
aside2questions.answer: Is-a-door.

aside2questions.question: Why is Arnold Schwarzenegger in your video?
aside2questions.answer: In his feature role as John Kimble in Kindergarten Cop, Arnold transforms from a one-dimensional, gruff police officer into a passionate teacher dedicated to learning. We feel this character is a perfect introduction to our learning management system (but mostly we just really like the movie).

lessons.aside3content: St. Isidore of Seville sought to compile all knowledge into an encyclopedia known as 'Etymologiae.' In the 20 books composing the encyclopedia, St. Isidore covers math, music, law, languages, atoms, elements, agriculture, metals, animals, and more. You can find ALL these topics covered within the Isidore LMS. UD is carrying on Isidore's legacy!

lessons.title: Getting Started with Isidore
lessons.description: Logging in and adding a profile picture.
lessons.overviewcontent: If you’ve never used Isidore before, fear not! This lesson will help you get started.
lessons.section1content: Watch this 1-minute video to learn how to log in and add a profile picture. While adding a profile picture may not seem important, there are places within Isidore where your picture will display, so we recommend changing it so your students can quickly identify and differentiate messages from you.
lessons.section2content: Log in and add your profile picture and name pronunciation.

section2steps.step: Click on your name in the top right corner. Click on 'Profile'.
Add picture: Click 'Edit Profile Picture' and add a picture of yourself. Make sure you remember to choose which sharing option you want so students can see your picture!
Add name pronunciation: Click 'Create Name Pronunciation' and follow the steps to record your name.

lessons.section3content: Complete the Quick Quiz below to earn credit for completing this lesson.

lti.description: It's a quick quiz, but you still will have needed to watch the video to get the answers right. So go watch if you haven't!
lti.title: Getting Started with Isidore Quiz

references.title: University of Dayton: Using NameCoach to Create an Environment of Inclusivity and Respect for Every Student

aside2questions.question: I don't have a UD account yet. How can I log in?
aside2questions.answer: Please contact the IT Service Center to obtain your credentials. You can reach them at itservicecenter@udayton.edu or (937) 229-3888. If your credentials are "in-the-works", contact eLearning to obtain a "guest" account.

aside2questions.question: What browsers work best with Isidore?
aside2questions.answer: We recommend Chrome and Firefox, though Edge and Safari are also supported.

aside2questions.question: Why is 2-factor authentication needed?
aside2questions.answer: As a part of the campus community, you play a part in keeping our campus safe - this includes from cyber attacks. Your password is the easiest way for attacks on our systems to happen, so the additional step of approving log ins on a secondary device is a critical step for safety.

aside2questions.question: What was that screen the presenter was writing on at the end of the video?
aside2questions.answer: That's the 'Canvas', a giant touch-sensitive video wall in the LTC Studio. Contact the LTC to learn how you can teach your class in that room in a future semester.

aside2questions.question: Who was the scary person in the 'horrific driver license photo'?
aside2questions.answer: That was the presenter, aged 15. The point is that the photo that is taken of you in the Flyer Card office for your ID somehow looks WORSE than driver license photos. Amazing.

lessons.aside3content: Our Isidore homepage has looked mighty different over the years. See all of Isidore's looks

lessons.title: Course Site Creation
lessons.description: Create Isidore sites for your classes.
lessons.overviewcontent: In this lesson, you will learn how to cite a site at first sight. *ba dum tsh* Well, maybe not precisely, but you will learn what Isidore sites are and how to create, organize, and manage them. At UD, instructors are responsible for creating their own sites for their courses, but eLearning staff is always happy to help if you get stuck.
lessons.section1content: Watch this 2 minute video to learn about Isidore sites.
lessons.section2content: You will now create your own Isidore site. If you would like to create a site for an actual course, you can follow the steps shown in the video. If you prefer to create a test site with a roster of fake students, follow the steps in the Creating a Test Site article listed in the Wiki Resources to the right. Don't be afraid, we promise you won't hurt anything!

section2steps.step: Let us know your site's title by completing the Quick Write below these steps.
An eLearning staff member will verify that you created a site, then, boom! You earned a Site Sighted badge!

lessons.section3content: Are you now a site creation whiz? Complete the Quick Quiz below to  earn credit for completing this lesson. Create a course site and submit it via the Quick Write below to earn your Site Sighted badge. Yes, we know, we really killed this joke.

lti.description: Take the three question quiz below to show us you know how to create Isidore sites.
lti.title: Course Site Creation Quiz

lti.description: Use the steps above to create a course site and then use the link below to submit your site to eLearning for credit.
lti.title: Sight my Site!

aside2questions.question: Why do instructors need to create Isidore sites themselves?
aside2questions.answer: UD does not require instructors to use Isidore, so we have no way of knowing who is using Isidore and who isn't any given term; thus, we ask that instructors create their own sites. Plus, you know better than we do what content should be copied over every semester!

aside2questions.question: What's the difference between an Isidore site and an Isidore tab?
aside2questions.answer: Lots of people call their Isidore sites, "tabs". They might also refer to the tools in their Isidore site (e.g. Syllabus, Announcements, Assignments, etc.) as tabs.

aside2questions.question: When are Isidore sites published to students?
aside2questions.answer: Isidore sites for the current term are published automatically at 8 AM on the first day of the term. At that time, we also unpublish all Isidore sites from the previous term.

aside2questions.question: I'm teaching this coming semester, but I don't see a roster available to me to create. What do I do?
aside2questions.answer: It could be a number of things. You may have selected the wrong term when beginning the site creation process (most classes are in terms that are called something like "Spring 2020" or "Fall 2020"). More likely is that you are not listed as the instructor of record for the class. Don't worry, you can still create the Isidore site for your roster! You just have to request it, then eLearning will review the request and approve the roster once we determine that you are indeed the instructor.

aside2questions.question: How soon before the term begins can I create my Isidore site?
aside2questions.answer: The rosters for the upcoming term become available in Isidore ten weeks prior to the start of the semester. If you want to create the site before then, just contact eLearning - we can set it up.

aside2questions.question: Oops! I goofed. How can I delete the site that I made?
aside2questions.answer: On Isidore homepage, click on the 'My Sites' tool. Check the box next to the site you want to delete, then press the 'Delete' button. On the next page, click the 'Mark for deletion' button.

lessons.aside3content: Approximately 90% of faculty members at UD use Isidore for at least one course.

modules.title: Isidore 101
modules.description: These lessons cover the basics of the most commonly (and easily) used tools in Isidore. We recommend including all of these tools in your course sites -- BUT only if you really do plan on using them. Don't add tools that you won't use!

lessons.title: Text Editor
lessons.description: Many useful features are hidden in this magic box.
lessons.overviewcontent: We're starting out with something that's not actually a definitive "tool" in Isidore, so sorry for the trick on this one. The rich-text editor, though, is a really important place to start because it has features that we'd hate for you to miss. These features will help you make your content accessible for all learners, as well as link your material to UD's Catholic heritage. We also think it's important to add your personality and YOUR expert voice whenever possible, so these features will help you do so.
lessons.section1content: A 2 minute overview of some of the features in the text editor.
lessons.section2content: The video was just a sample of all that is possible with the rich-text editor. Play around with the buttons yourself to see all that's possible. Only then will you be able to pass the quiz.

lti.description: Check out the CK Editor article in the Wiki resources to help you answer the questions in the quiz.
lti.title: Text Editor Quiz

references.title: The Human Touch and Your Digital Personality
Common Themes in the Mission and Identity at the University of Dayton

aside2questions.question: Are all text editors in Isidore rich-text editors?
aside2questions.answer: No. There are places where only plain-text editors are available, so you'll just have to be boring in those places.

aside2questions.question: Is it okay to just have black text on a white background? I'm not really into all this extra stuff.
aside2questions.answer: Sure thing! In fact, having too much color or crazy distractions is actually BAD for student learning. We do recommend adding pictures, at least, when they make sense to use (e.g. diagrams, pictures of the textbook, etc.).

lessons.aside3title: What's eLearning's favorite rich-text editor tool?
lessons.aside3content: We all answered differently, so the author gets to answer on behalf of the team, mwahaha. Our favorite is the remove format button in the top row of the editor. This tool lets us remove all formatting from the text box, meaning we don't have to individually un-bold and un-italicize everything. Huge timesaver!

lessons.title: Overview
lessons.description: Your course landing page. Use it well.
lessons.overviewcontent: We beg you. Do something, ANYTHING, with your Overview tool. Please add something other than the catalog description of the class.
lessons.section1content: See some examples of different faculty members' Overviews in the 1 minute video below.
lessons.section2content: Have a creative idea for an Overview? Show us!
lessons.section2prereq: To complete this step, you must either have an existing site that you can use, or you must first create a test site as instructed in the Creating Course Sites lesson.

section2steps.step: Navigate to the site where you'll add your cool Overview.
Create the best landing page in Isidore using all the information you have learned.

lessons.section3content: We believe you now know everything required to make your Overview pop. Well, we'll believe you know everything AFTER you pass the quiz.

lti.description: Take the three question quiz below to show us you know how to add the Cheer Cup widget to your Overview.
lti.title: Overview Quiz

lti.description: Make your Overview page something different than the course descrpition, then use the link below to submit your site to eLearning for credit.
lti.title: Review my Overview

aside2questions.question: I only use Isidore to post resources and my syllabus. Why should I do anything with my Isidore site's landing page?
aside2questions.answer: Instructors at UD use Isidore in such differing and oftentimes perplexing ways that it's really easy for students to be confused on where to look for course resources. We've seen people post the syllabus in, no joke, all of these tools: Announcements, Messages, Resources, Syllabus, Lessons, Calendar, and Chat Room. So while YOU may think it's obvious where everything is, your students might not, so it's helpful to, at the very least, tell them where to look in the site for your stuff. Secondly, because it's fun.

aside2questions.question: How do you know students make judgments about my Isidore site?
aside2questions.answer: We ask them. Regularly.

aside2questions.question: I'd like to add something more interactive to my Overview. Is that possible?
aside2questions.answer: You betcha. We recommend adding the Commons widget by clicking on the Manage Overview button in the top right corner of the tool. The Commons widget is similar to a social media style newsfeed where you and your students can post quick links to articles, comments, questions, etc.

aside2questions.question: Are there any examples I can look at?
aside2questions.answer: Many faculty members have graciously let us share their creative Overview pages. Check them out in the Additional Articles section above. If you want yours on this list, just let us know!

lessons.aside3content: The content on your Overview doesn't have to be static!! Change it throughout the semester. Put up a pumpkin joke or or a black cat for Halloween. Add an easter egg for Easter. Do something more interesting than those suggestions.

lessons.title: Syllabus
lessons.description: Don't add it as a Word Doc.
lessons.overviewcontent: You're going to be shocked to learn that this tool is for posting your syllabus. Who would have guessed from its name?
lessons.section1content: Spoiler alert. Stop reading right now if you don't want to have the surprise spoiled which it already was on the main page for the Isidore 101 module. Hopefully by this point in the lengthy paragraph that this is you have stopped reading, thus making this a good enough prevention of spoilers. Okay, here is the spoiler: Don't post your Syllabus as a Word Doc.
lessons.section2content: If you somehow missed it in literally 3 different areas prior to this quiz, we'll tell you again for some help on the quiz: do not post your syllabus as a Word Doc.

lti.description: Prove you know everything about syllabuses.
lti.title: Syllabus Quiz

references.title: Finding the Syllabus Template in Isidore
How to Create a Syllabus: Advice Guide from The Chronicle

aside2questions.question: How do you know students don't like the syllabus as a Word Doc?
aside2questions.answer: We ask them. Regularly. Last time we asked, only 5% of students said they would want the syllabus posted as a Word Doc or PDF as opposed to have it pasted it in Isidore. To be fair, a large percentage also said they wanted it printed and distrubted in class, but we don't want to kill the trees.

aside2questions.question: Copying and pasting my syllabus into Isidore messes up the formatting. How can I get it to look nice?
aside2questions.answer: Really wish we had a snappy answer for this one. Like rocket science, maintaining formatting between things is just hard. But we can help. Shoot the Word Doc version of the Syllabus to elearning@udayton.edu, and we'll see what we can do.

aside2questions.question: If my syllabus is 32 pages long, is it really still okay to just paste in to Isidore?
aside2questions.answer: First, 32 pages seems . . . excessive. You might want to trim it down or choose a smaller font. If your syllabus is longer than average, then we do recommend adding multiple expandable/collapsible sections to the Syllabus tool (such as 'University Policies', 'Course Information', 'Schedule', and 'Grading Policy') so students can quickly jump to the sections they need most.

aside2questions.question: Where can I find imoprtant University dates while I'm making my course schedule?
aside2questions.answer: UD's Academic Calendar at calendar.udayton.edu.

aside2questions.question: Okay, I get the point, no Word Docs. I don't want to fool around with formatting though, so how do I save it as a PDF?
aside2questions.answer: This is a great question as it's really not immediately clear that this is possible to do. If you have your Word Doc open, press the File button, then the Save As option. Find a location on your computer to save the file. Then, on the same screen where you can rename the document while saving, there is a "Save as type" menu. Click that and choose "PDF". Press save, and you're done!

lessons.aside3content: Isidore is designed to be responsive, which means that it works well on mobile devices like phones. You know what doesn't work well on phones? Word Docs.

lessons.title: Announcements
lessons.description: More effective than yelling over students as they walk out the door.
lessons.overviewcontent: Use the Announcements tool to post messages for your students. You may attach documents and add links. By default, Announcements are also sent to students’ emails, so you can be *sure they see the message.     *seeing the message still not guaranteed.
lessons.section1content: No students were harmed by yelling in the making of this 1 minute video.
lessons.section2content: It's now time for you to try posting your own Announcement.
lessons.section2prereq: To complete this step, you must either have an existing site that you can use, or you must first create a test site as instructed in the Creating Course Sites lesson.

section2steps.step: Post an Announcement. WARNING: if you are testing this feature in a live course site that is published, your students will receive an email.

lessons.section3content: We hope you studied up for this one. It's a toughie.

lti.description: Take the three question quiz below to establish your Announcements experitse.
lti.title: Announcements Quiz

references.title: When You Communicate with Students, Tone Matters

aside2questions.question: Where do students see Announcements?
aside2questions.answer: Students have the option to see Announcements in multiple locations. By default, they can see links to all of their Announcements on their Isidore homepage. They would also see the links to the Announcements on your course site homepage. If you didn’t change the default behavior, students would receive an email notification including the text of the announcement.

aside2questions.question: Do Announcements work if the site is unpublished?
aside2questions.answer: Not really. The Announcement will be posted, but an email will not be delivered to students’ inboxes, and they would have no way of seeing the Announcement until the site is published.

aside2questions.question: Will I receive an email notification about the Announcement as the instructor?
aside2questions.answer: Yes. Other instructors in your site, if any,  will also receive the email notification.

aside2questions.question: Can I schedule Announcements?
aside2questions.answer: You bet! Just choose the 'Specify Dates' option after writing the text for your Announcement. Pick the dates the Announcement should be visible, and it will appear (and disappear) on the selected dates.

aside2questions.question: Can I save an Announcement as a draft?
aside2questions.answer: Definitely. Choose the 'Hide' option after writing your Announcement, then press the Post Announcement button. It will be hidden until you edit the Announcement and change that setting to Show.

aside2questions.question: Can I delete an Announcement?
aside2questions.answer: Yes - but you cannot delete the email notification from students' inboxes once sent, so proofread before you post!

lessons.aside3content: 432,000 Announcements have been posted in Isidore since 2008. Y'all do a lot of announcing.

lessons.title: Resources
lessons.description: Keep this tool organized!
lessons.overviewcontent: The Resources tool is a required tool in your Isidore site, meaning you can't delete it. This is because any attachment, file, or cat picture you add to your site is actually stored in the Resources tool, whether you know it or not. While Resources isn't the only tool you can use to share course materials with your students, it's the easiest to get started with.
lessons.section1content: Watch the 1 minute video overview of Resources tool below to learn the answer to the question your students will ask you the most.
lessons.section2content: You now have the power to distribute course resources. Use your power wisely.

lti.description: You know the drill! Answer 3 questions to prove you watched the video.
lti.title: Resources Quiz

references.title: UD Students Answer: What is the Single Most Important Thing an Instructor can do in Isidore?

aside2questions.question: I'm already using the Lessons tool to deliver course resources. Should I also make them organized in Resources?
aside2questions.answer: No. We recommend that instructors use Resources OR Lessons - but never both. If you have everything all nicely organized in Lessons, we suggest hiding the Resources tool so students won't be looking in multiple locations for the materials.

aside2questions.question: Is there a better way to deliver course resources than this tool?
aside2questions.answer: The Lessons tool allows you to organize your Resources in more of a webpage format. In Lessons, you can add textual context above each resource, add images, add learning activities next to the resources, and more. However, the learning curve is higher with Lessons, so if you're just getting started, you should stick to Resources for the time being.

aside2questions.question: Can I add Resources that are hidden from students?
aside2questions.answer: Yes. We suggest create a folder in Resources in which you will store resources that students shouldn't see. Next to the folder, click on Actions -> Edit Details -> Hide this folder and its contents -> Update. BUT WE ARE WARNING YOU NOW. BE. CAREFUL. Instructors HAVE added test keys then mistakeningly made the folder visible to students, and students got the answers to exams. Consider yourself warned.

lessons.aside3content: If you post an article in your Resources tool that looks like this: 'http://rave.ohiolink.edu/ejournals/article/345270862' -- your students (and YOU) have literally no idea what that is except that it's probably a journal article of some kind. You can rename the resources you post within Resources by clicking on Actions -> Edit Details -> Display Name. Please do this!!

lessons.title: Roster
lessons.description: Get to know your students. Well, at least their faces.
lessons.overviewcontent: Your students will probably think you're a nerd if you come in on the first day and have all their names memorized. But with the roster tool, you could totally do this.
lessons.section1content: There's more to the Roster tool than just seeing their faces. You can also see their academic years, majors, minors. You can also see who the honors students are, so you know who will be 'pulling a Hermione' during your lectures.

lti.description: This quiz is easier than memorizing all your students' names, but you should probably do that, too.
lti.title: Roster Quiz

references.title: Pronouncing Students' Names Correctly Should be a Big Deal

aside2questions.question: What can students see in the Roster tool?
aside2questions.answer: Students will see a list of their peers and instructors, as well as their name recordings. They CANNOT see their peers' profile pictures unless the other students have opted-in to sharing their pictures.

aside2questions.question: My students haven't recorded their name pronunciations. Can I make them do so?
aside2questions.answer: No. But I'd bet they would respond favorably to a bribe in the form of a bonus point or two.

aside2questions.question: What is a 'pulling a Hermione'?
aside2questions.answer: A reference to a terribly bright literary character who often participates in class. Also, you should read Harry Potter!

aside2questions.question: Because of the spelling of 'pronounce,' shouldn't 'pronunciation' really be spelled 'pronounciation'? With a 'u'?
aside2questions.answer: 100%. After typing this incorrectly ~47 times throughout this lesson, the author would like if you got on board to sign a petition to change the spelling of this word.

lessons.title: Attendance
lessons.description: Track your students' attendance.
lessons.overviewcontent: In my day, I had to track my own attendance by marking tallies on the back of my agenda. This was possibly not a foolproof system. My, my how times have changed. Record your students' attendance in Isidore so there are no discrepencies between your tracking and their tracking..
lessons.section1content: Taking Attendance in Isidore is a choose-your-own adventure. Watch the 1 minute video to see all the adventure options. 'Adventure' is overselling the experience, but hey, at least you have options.
lessons.section2prereq: To complete this step, you must either have an existing site that you can use, or you must first create a test site as instructed in the Creating Course Sites lesson.

section2steps.step: Figure the rest out for yourself. ;)

lti.description: You might be tempted to skip this quiz, but you shouldn't. There's a big time-saving tip in it.
lti.title: Attendance Quiz

references.title: Why I Don't Take Attendance from The Chronicle
Class Attendance in College: A Review of the Relationship of Class Attendance with Grades

aside2questions.question: I have 83 students in a single Isidore site. Is there a faster way to take attendance than clicking on each student?
aside2questions.answer: Use the 'Mark Displayed Students As Present' feature to mark all students as present first. Then go back and make adjustments for the absent students. Nb: You might want to do the opposite of this on St. Patrick's Day . . .

aside2questions.question: I don't care if my students are late or if they left early. Can I get rid of those statuses?
aside2questions.answer: Yes. Click on the 'Settings' tab at the top of the Attendance tool. Deselect any statuses you don't want to see and press 'Save Settings'.

aside2questions.question: Do I have to take attendance?
aside2questions.answer: Attendance is required for first-year students, so yes, please track their attendance. Otherwise, it's up to you. If you have a grade associated with attendance, though, you should keep track just so there are no grade complaints at the end of the semester.

aside2questions.question: Can I set up grading with Attendance?
aside2questions.answer: Visit the 'Grading' tab at the top of the Attendance tool to set up grading for Attendance. If you want to define rules (such as if a student misses 3 classes, take 15 points off their attendance grade) for attendance, you can also set those up. If you get stuck with those, give us a call. It's a lot of logic.

aside2questions.question: Can I save an Announcement as a draft?
aside2questions.answer: Definitely. Choose the 'Hide' option after writing your Announcement, then press the Post Announcement button. It will be hidden until you edit the Announcement and change that setting to Show.

lessons.aside3content: We give you the freedom to name your attendance items ANYTHING you want. You all take that freedom and name most of your attendance items, 'Attendance.'

lessons.title: Calendar
lessons.description: You should add this one. Students like it.
lessons.overviewcontent: Okay, now that you've added the tool to your course site, do nothing else. Don't touch.
lessons.section1content: Watch this 1 minute video to see all the nothing you should do with this tool.

lti.description: It's important you prove to us you know the Calendar tool.
lti.title: Calendar Quiz

lessons.aside3title: How do you describe someone who knows a lot about tech stuff?

modules.title: Accessibility
modules.description: This set of lessons introduces the concepts of digital accessibility in the context of teaching here at the University of Dayton. Additional Resources are provided with each module to provide optional, in-depth training to complete your understanding of how to make all of your course content accessible.

lessons.title: Visual Disabilities
lessons.description: How can you make your content accessible for students with visual impairments?
lessons.overviewcontent: Students with profound visual impairments use screen reading software to read files and web pages. How does this inform the way you construct and organize your content? And how does color-blindness affect your use of color?
lessons.section1content: This video explains the essentials for producing content that is accessible to students with visual impairments.
lessons.section2content: In addition to watching the video, please look through the Additional Resources. Then you will be ready for the following assessments.

lti.description: The following quiz will measure your understanding of the essential elements described in the video.
lti.title: Visual Disabilities Quiz

lti.description: Complete the following assignment.
lti.title: Visual Disabilities Assignment

aside2questions.question: How detailed should I be when writing alt text for an image?
aside2questions.answer: Be brief, but be sure to describe the essential elements of the image. If the graphic is supposed to make the audience think or feel something, be sure your alt text leads that direction.

aside2questions.question: Should I always start with H1?
aside2questions.answer: This gets tricky. The main thing is that you use header tags. That's 99% of the battle. Often Isidore has existing headers already in place. In most cases in Isidore, it's recommended you start with H2.

lessons.aside3content: The Office of eLearning has invited expert screen-reader users to evaluate Isidore. Additionally, Isidore is based on the open source LMS Sakai, which has accessibility as crucial foundation of the software.

lessons.title: Auditory Disabilities
lessons.description: How can you make your content accessible for students with hearing impairments?
lessons.overviewcontent: Videos have two components, images and sound. For students with hearing impairments, you will need to ensure that all audio components are "captured" and presented to students. This is most often in the form of closed captioning. The bonus is that captions are part of universal design and are beneficial to every type of learner.
lessons.section1content: This video explains the essentials for producing content that is accessible to students with hearing impairments, and it also explains how captions can be beneficial to students without hearing impairments.
lessons.section2content: In addition to watching the video, please look through the Additional Resources. Then you will be ready for the following assessments.

lti.description: The following quiz will measure your understanding of the essential elements described in the video.
lti.title: Auditory Disabilities Quiz

lti.description: Complete the following assignment.
lti.title: Auditory Disabilities Assignment

references.title: How to Locate Captioned Videos and Create Your Own
National Center on Accessible Educational Materials: Closed Captioning

aside2questions.question: Do I have to pay for captions?
aside2questions.answer: Not if it's for a course. If you upload videos to Warpwire for the purpose of providing instructional content, the Office of eLearning will take care of the captions for you.

aside2questions.question: How can I ensure the captions are accurate?
aside2questions.answer: You are still responsible for the accuracy of the captions, so please check them. If you find inaccuracies please contact the Office of eLearning.

lessons.aside3content: Warpwire videos can actually be searched. For example, if you wanted to search a video for the moment the speaker says the word, 'Malaysia', you just click the search icon type 'Malaysia'. This is possible due to the presence of captions.

lessons.title: Cognitive, Motor, & Other Disabilities
lessons.description: How can you make your content accessible for students with cognitive, motor, and other disabilities?
lessons.overviewcontent: Many of the accessibility techniques you use for people with visual disabilities are helpful for individuals with cognitive and motor disabilities, but putting extra attention on organization and clarity is definitely something you should prioritize.
lessons.section1content: This video explains the essentials for producing content that is accessible to students with cognitive and motor disabilities. There also is discussion on content for students with seizure disorders.
lessons.section2content: In addition to watching the video, please look through the Additional Resources. Then you will be ready for the following assessments.

lti.description: The following quiz will measure your understanding of the essential elements described in the video.
lti.title: Other Disabilities Quiz

lti.description: Complete the following assignment.
lti.title: Other Disabilities Assignment

aside2questions.question: What if my content is inherently complex?
aside2questions.answer: It's not about how complicated your content is, but rather how clearly you present it. Be organized. Use headers and spacing appropriately.

aside2questions.question: What if a student is lacking in basic study skills?
aside2questions.answer: Direct them to contact the Office of Learning Resources or contact the Student Success Team.

lessons.aside3content: A study revealed that simply presenting the same instructions in an easier to read font, caused students to see the tasks as easier. Clarity and organization make a difference.

lessons.title: Accessible Documents
lessons.description: How can you make your files, such as Word and Powerpoint, accessible for students with disabilities?
lessons.overviewcontent: All documents utilized in class must be made available in electronic format to students. This is important not just for students with visual and hearing impairments but for all students who may have academic accommodations for attention issues and processing disorders. This impacts approximately 5-10 percent of students. What steps must you take to ensure that the electronic version is completely accessible?
lessons.section1content: This video explains the essentials for delivering accessible files.
lessons.section2content: In addition to watching the video, please look through the Additional Resources. Then you will be ready for the following assessments.

lti.description: The following quiz will measure your understanding of the essential elements described in the video.
lti.title: Accessible Documents Quiz

lti.description: Complete the following assignment.
lti.title: Accessible Documents Assignment

references.title: Microsoft Word Training on Accessibility in Word
Microsoft Word Training on Accessibility in PowerPoint
National Center on Accessible Educational Materials: Closed Captioning
National Center on Accessible Educational Materials: Accessible Documents

aside2questions.question: What do I do if my existing documents are not accessible?
aside2questions.answer: In the Additional Resources, you'll see a link to Sensus Access. This can be very useful in terms of converting text that is unreadable to readable text. It will not necessarily convert all headings and it certainly won't put alt text in there, but it gives you a good base to start from.

aside2questions.question: I don't like the way the headers look in MS Word, can I change the look?
aside2questions.answer: You bet! In the ribbon you can right mouse click on the header you want to change and it will change it for all instances of the header.

lessons.aside3content: Google Docs and Slides also have the same general accessible properties as their Microsoft Office counterparts.

lessons.title: Accessibility of Outside Materials
lessons.description: If you intend to use materials that you do not produce yourself, how can you be sure they are accessible?
lessons.overviewcontent: Most faculty include some externally produced content in their course required course materials. This could be articles from the web, YouTube videos, publisher resources, and software. If you are requiring your students to use it, you need to be sure it is accessible.
lessons.section1content: This video explains the essentials for ensuring outside materials are accessible.
lessons.section2content: In addition to watching the video, please look through the Additional Resources. Then you will be ready for the following assessments.

lti.description: The following quiz will measure your understanding of the essential elements described in the video.
lti.title: Outside Materials Quiz

lti.description: Complete the following assignment.
lti.title: Outside Materials Assignment

references.title: How to Find Specialized Formats of Print Materials
How to Select Accessible Digital Materials

aside2questions.question: My chair picked my materials, what if they're not accessible?
aside2questions.answer: Say something, but be tactful about it. Offer to contact the vendor or publisher. Your chair can later decide whether you'll continue with those materials.

aside2questions.question: How can I ensure the captions are accurate?
aside2questions.answer: You are still responsible for the accuracy of the captions, so please check them. If you find inaccuracies please contact the Office of eLearning.

lessons.aside3content: Most electronic textbooks are accessible, and they also tend to be cheaper. Just remember to check before you buy.

modules.title: Zoom Video Conferencing
modules.description: Let us introduce you to Zoom, the University of Dayton’s chosen platform for video conferencing. While Zoom is primarily used for synchronous learning and web conferencing, there are some unique ways you can use Zoom to enhance your face to face class and increase student engagement. This training module will explain the potential uses, how to acquire zoom, navigate the zoom room, and utilize the best practices for facilitating a synchronous session.

video.title: What's Zoom Got to Do with Me?

lessons.title: Getting Ready to Zoom
lessons.description: Activating your account and downloading Zoom.
lessons.overviewcontent: Whether you are planning on teaching online, adding interactivity to your face to face course, or just want to check out video conferencing, this lesson will help you to activate your Zoom account, download the client app, schedule/manage meetings, and tell you how to get support.
lessons.section1content: Watch this video for information on how to get started using Zoom.
lessons.section2content:
Personalize your Zoom settings to prepare for your first facilitation.
  1. Log into your zoom account at https://go.udayton.edu/zoom.
  2. Upload an image for your profile in your profile settings.
  3. Explore the settings menu and customize in the manner that works best for your needs.

aside2questions.question: Do I need to activate my Zoom account if I am also teaching with 2U and use Zoom for that platform?
aside2questions.answer: The University of Dayton provisioned faculty with Zoom accounts separate from the ones provided by 2U for the online program. However, Zoom will only allow you to register one account with each email.  Registering your University of Dayton Zoom account will disconnect your 2U account. If you have a 2U account, please use your 2U account for all Zoom activity.

aside2questions.question: Do I need to download my Zoom video recording and upload them into the Warpwire video tool for students to access?
aside2questions.answer: No, this is not necessary if you are using Zoom within Isidore (recommend for class meetings). Students can access the video recordings from the Zoom tool in the Isidore course site.  All recordings are automatically closed captioned with timestamps.

aside2questions.question: Do I have to send an invite out to all my students if I hold an online session?
aside2questions.answer: Nope!  Students will be able to view the links to upcoming sessions and click “join” right from Isidore (if you are using Zoom within Isidore, which is HIGHLY recommended). Yet another benefit of utilizing UD’s awesome LMS! You may want to send a friendly reminder to students though --just in case.

lessons.aside3content: The first concepts of video conferencing were developed in the 1870s, as part of an extension of audio devices. The first actual developments of the video telephone began in the late 1920s with the AT&T company Bell Labs and John Logie Baird. AT&T experimented with video phones in 1927. (Business Matters, https://www.bmmagazine.co.uk/tech/history-video-conferencing/_).

lessons.title: Zoom Classroom Basics
lessons.description: Learn the basic tools of the Zoom classroom.
lessons.overviewcontent: All set up and ready to go?  In this lesson we will review the basic features of the Zoom classroom.  Once you have these down, adding the advanced features will be a simple feat.
lessons.section1content: Get ready to take flight in your online classroom. This video will explain all the basic tools you will need to facilitate a quality class or meeting.
lessons.section2content:
Try out your new skills as a Zoom facilitator.

Schedule a meeting for Zoom and invite a friend. Record the session and review the recording afterward to identify any changes in approach you may need in your next use of Zoom. While in the session, ensure you can be heard and seen well with your webcam. Play around with the features and ensure that you feel comfortable using them. Alternatively, contact an eLearning representative (elearning@udyaton.edu) to schedule a test meeting.

references.title: Webinar Recording: Improve Your Virtual Presentation Skills

aside2questions.question: I’m ready to try the more challenging aspects of managing a live Zoom session. How do I manage creating and using polls and breakout rooms?
aside2questions.answer: Super! Zoom has great training on these topics. Check out the links in resources.

aside2questions.question: Should I manage my settings from the Zoom tool itself or from my Zoom account at go.udayton.edu/zoom?
aside2questions.answer: You can manage settings from either location but please be aware that there are more settings in your online account than are available through the Zoom tool itself. You cannot manage settings from the Zoom tool in Isidore.

lessons.aside3content: The class session report in “Past Meetings” tab will tell you how long your students were present in your class session and how engaged they were during that session.  The attentiveness rating is based on participation in the chat box, polls, discussion, video, etc.

lessons.title: Synchronous Teaching Pedagogy
lessons.description: How to ensure student engagement and collaboration are a part of your synchronous teaching.
lessons.overviewcontent: It takes a significant effort to convert quality instructional plans into well-designed, high-engagement synchronous learning experiences. In this lesson, we will talk about some of the top skills that keep students active and learning in a synchronous session.
lessons.section1content: Facilitating a synchronous class takes careful planning to provide for the necessary student engagement and collaboration. Find out more by watching the video below.

lti.description:
Use the link below to submit your response. You will be asked to answer the following two prompts.
  1. Have you already taught online before with a synchronous tool? Discuss the challenges of maintaining student engagement in a tool like Zoom. What areas of improvement do you see that can be addressed and improved based on this training?
  2. During a synchronous class session, you notice that one of your students is not participating. You have tried multiple ways to engage the class, including the chatbox, whiteboard, microphone and breakout rooms to no avail. How would you address the student and encourage a higher level of engagement?
lti.title: Share your experience

references.title: 3 Ways To Use Polls In Meetings
Enhanced Productivity Via Shared Screen Annotation
PPT Template for AV Support and Agenda
Learning to Teach Online – Coursera Course
Improve Student Success with an Online Learning Community
9 Proven Ways for Instructors to Address Online Student Retention
Breakout rooms in virtual classrooms: why and how.

aside2questions.question: What is the recommended ratio of instructor lecture to student contribution in the online classroom?
aside2questions.answer: Answers on this vary but the consensus is that lecture by the instructor should never exceed the amount of time spent participating in interactive tasks such as questioning and discussion, group work, or other learning that is active for students.

aside2questions.question: What is a creative activity to utilize in a breakout room?
aside2questions.answer: A current trend in online learning is to create an actual “Breakout Room” room.  The instructor builds a series of puzzles and questions, centered on the learning topic, that have to be solved by the students. This is  similar to the Escape and Breakout rooms that are popular group outing activities. Different groups can race against one another to see who solves the breakout first.
